titleproper.value:
Guide to the George Folsom Papers<lb/><date>1821-1866</date><lb/>
 <num>MS 222</num>

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-09-27T20:17:57</date>

abstract.value: Correspondence and a few papers, 1821-1866, primarily letters received by George Folsom (1802-1869) from authors, politicians, historians, artists, librarians, booksellers, and ethnologists. Included is material relating to family matters, his service as New York State Senator (Native American Party, or Know Nothings), 1845-1847, and chargé d'affaires to the Netherlands, 1850-1853, as well as his associations with the American Antiquarian Society, New-York Historical Society, and other learned societies.

p.value: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)
This collection should be cited as George Folsom Papers, MS 222, New-York Historical Society.

In his long career <emph render="bold">George Folsom</emph> (1802-1869) adopted varied, interchangeable, and occasionally overlapping roles, among them attorney, historian, author, librarian, antiquarian, politician, diplomat, and ethnologist. He was a member (and sometime officer) of the American Antiquarian Society, New-York Historical Society, Maine Historical Society, Vermont Historical Society, American Geographical and Statistical Society, Athenaeum Association, Century Association, Union League Club, and American Ethnological Society, of which he was president for the last decade of his life. Most notably, he sat in the New York State Senate (1845-1847), and served as chargé d'affaires (the diplomatic official who heads an embassy in the absence of an ambassador) to the Netherlands (1850-1853).
Invitations, receipts, and the occasional bookseller's prospectus are scattered throughout the collection.

subject.value: Learned institutions and societies  --  New York (State)  --  New York.

dsc.value:
Box 1: Letters, 1821-1832175063Letters1750731821-182411Letters178685182512Scope and Contents Note

See 1825 March 4, from Nathaniel Hazelton Carter, a Dartmouth professor who lost his position after the Dartmouth College Case (a.k.a., Dartmouth College v. Woodward).

See 1825 May 24, introducing Folsom to Stephen Longfellow, U.S. Representative from Maine.

Letters1786861826 February-August13Letters1786871826 October-December14Letters178688182715Letters1786901828-182916Letters178691183017Letters178692183118Scope and Contents Note

See 1831 October 24, Folsom's certificate of election to membership in the American Antiquarian Society.

Letters178693183219Box 2: Letters, 1833-1835 April178694Letters1786951833 January-April21Letters1786961833 May-June22Letters1787081833 July-December23Letters from Edward Everett1787091832-185224Scope and Contents Note

On politics and the acquisition of a portrait of Hugo Grotius. Edward Everett (1794-1865) was an American politician, pastor, educator, diplomat, and orator.

Letters1787101834 January-June25Letters1787111834 July-December26Letters from Albert Gallatin1787121834-184427Scope and Contents Note

On Native American tribes and languages, and documents in London relating to the colonial history of New York. Refer to the Manuscript Department card catalog for Folsom's responses to Gallatin. Albert Gallatin (1761-1849) was a Swiss-American politician, diplomat, ethnologist and linguist.

Letters1787131835 January-April28Box 3: Letters, 1835 May-1840178714Letters1787151835 May-August31Letters1787161835 September-December32Letters178720183633Letters from George Bancroft1787211836-185034Scope and Contents Note

On historical and literary matters. George Bancroft (1800-1891) was an American historian and statesman.

Letters on seamstresses1787251836-183735Scope and Contents Note

Includes two copies of a printed broadside, Order of Excercises, for the Public Meeting in behalf of the Tailoresses and Seamstresses' Benevolent Society, Wednesday Evening, December 28th, 1836, and three letters from Irish-American publisher and economist Mathew Carey dated 1837 (January 24, February 1, and February 7).

Letters178726183736Letters1787271838 January-June37Scope and Contents Note

See 1838 April 11, from Thaddeus Mason Harris, at Boston, to Folsom at the New-York Historical Society, regarding publication by the Massachusetts Historical Society of John Winthrop's 1630 sermon "A Model of Christian Charity." Harris (1768–1842) was a Harvard librarian and Unitarian minister.

Letters1787281838 July-December38Letters1787291839 January-June39Letters1787301839 July-December310Letters1787311840 January-June311Letters1787321840 July-December312Box 4: Letters, 1841-1845 March178748Letters1787491841 January-July41Letters1787501841 August-December42Letters from John Romeyn Brodhead1787511841-184343Scope and Contents Note

From The Hague and London, reporting on Brodhead's progress in procuring material from European archives to fill gaps in New York State archives. John Romeyn Brodhead (1814-1873) was an American historical scholar.

Letters from Jared Sparks1787521841-185944Scope and Contents Note

On historical and literary matters. Jared Sparks (1789-1866) was an American historian, educator, and Unitarian minister.

Letters from Peter G. Stuyvesant1787531841-184745Scope and Contents Note

Letters and some papers from New York City, mostly concerning the controversy surrounding the opening of Stuyvesant Square. Peter G. Stuyvesant (1778-1847) was the maternal uncle of George Folsom's wife, Margaret Cornelia (Winthrop) Folsom.

Letters178755184246Letters1787561843 January-May47Letters1787581843 June-September48Letters1787591844 January-July49Letters1787601844 August-December410Letters1787611845 January411Letters1787621845 February412Letters1787641845 March 1-12413Letters1787651845 March 15-31414Scope and Contents Note

See 1845 March 31, from Henry R. Schoolcraft on a census of the Native American population, and the New-York Historical Society's committee on the subject of a new name for the United States. Schoolcraft (1793-1864) was an American geographer.

Box 5: Letters, 1845 April-1846 June178763Letters1787661845 April 1-1251Letters1787671845 April 16-3052Letters1787681845 May-June53Letters1787691845 July-December54Letters to Folsom in Albany, N.Y., as senator178822[1845-1847]55Letters1787701846 January-February 1456Letters1787711846 February 17-March 1257Letters1787721846 March 15-April58Letters1787731846 May-June59Box 6: Letters, 1846 July-1848178774Letters1787751846 July-December61Letters1787781847 January62Letters1787791847 February63Letters1787801847 March64Scope and Contents Note

See 1847 March 2, from Townsend Harris, president of the New York City Board of Education, on the establishment of a "Free Academy," today's City College.

Letters1787811847 April65Scope and Contents Note

See 1847 April [26], from William Hunt, at Lexington, Greene County, N.Y., requesting Folsom's personal details for inclusion in The New York Biographical Sketch Book, published in 1848 under the title The American Biographical Sketch Book. With prospectus and subscription form.

Letters1787821847 May-December66Letters1787831847 March-August67Letters1787841847 September-December68Box 7: Letters, 1849-1852 September178785Letters1787861849 January-June71Letters1787871849 July-December72Letters178791[1840s-1850s]73Letters178792185074Scope and Contents Note

See 1850 January 8, from J. F. Butterworth regarding the establishment of a branch of the United States Mint in New York.

Letters178793185175Letters1787941852 January-April76Scope and Contents Note

See 1852 March 17, from Eastman Johnson, at Venice, on the rigors of his European travels and comments on art: "Florence is beautiful, tho. I was somewhat disappointed in its pictures. The more I see of old pictures the more humbug I find in them, & I have had a surfeit these past few days." Johnson (1824-1906) was an artist and co-founder of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Letters1787951852 May-September77Box 8: Letters, 1852 October-1855178796Letters1787991852 October-December81Letters1788001853 January-May82Letters1788011853 June-December83Letters from August Belmont1788051853-185684Scope and Contents Note

On matters of transition and consular affairs. August Belmont (1813-1890) was a German-American politician, financier, and Folsom's successor as chargé d'affaires to the Netherlands.

Letters178806185485Scope and Contents Note

See 1854 December 19, from painter John Gadsby Chapman, at Rome, on cholera there and the progress of pictures ordered.

Letters178807185586Box 9: Letters, 1856-1866178808Letters1788091856 January-April91Letters1788101856 May-June92Letters1788111856 July-October93Scope and Contents Note

See 1856 July 30, in French, from Paris, on stationery featuring a portrait of Tadeusz Kościuszko.

Letters1788121857-185994Letters178813186095Scope and Contents Note

See 1860 March 29, pictorial cover of the Delavan House [hotel], Albany, N.Y.

See 1860 November 15, request to have Folsom's portrait painted for the Athenaeum Club. Signed by George E. Waring Jr. and others.

Letters178814186196Letters1788151862-186397Scope and Contents Note

See 1862 March 25, on stationery featuring a portrait of General Ambrose Burnside.

See 1863 January 23, includes a carte de visite photograph of a mature woman.

Letters178816186498Letters1788171865-186699Box 10: Letters to Folsom and family, undated178818Undated, to Folsom and family178819undated101Undated, to Folsom in Maine178820undated102Undated, to Folsom in Massachusetts178821undated103Undated, to Folsom in Europe178823undated104Undated, from correspondents A-L178824undated105Scope and Contents Note

Includes material from Park Benjamin Sr. (2 letters); Hamilton Fish (2 invitations); Mr. and Mrs. Alexander J. Hamilton (2 calling cards); and a letter from Washington Hunt, governor of New York, 1851-1852.

Undated, from correspondents M-Z178825undated106Scope and Contents Note

Includes material from Rembrandt Peale (2 letters, one referencing Folsom's portrait of Revolutionary War General Anthony Wayne; see N-YHS museum accession no. 1861.4) and Commodore Matthew C. Perry (a note, in his hand, written on his calling card).

Undated, unidentified, loose covers, etc.178826undated107Scope and Contents Note

Includes a photocopy of In Memoriam, an 1871 biographical sketch by Folsom's daughter, Helen Stuyvesant Folsom. For original, request call number: Pamph CT275.F65 F65 1871.
